newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: IMF mission in Almaty to examine Kazakh reforms.
newsitem.headline: IMF mission in Almaty to examine Kazakh reforms.

text.p: A mission from the International Monetary Fund arrived in Kazakhstan on Monday where it plans to take a look at its $446 million programme in the oil-rich former Soviet republic, a senior fund official said.
The IMF agreed a $446 million Extended Fund Facility last year and approved a first disbursement in January.
"The objective of the mission is to examine progress under the programme," David Hoelscher, the fund's resident representative in Kazakhstan, told Reuters on Monday.

Under the programme, the government plans to cut annual inflation to 15-17 percent this year from 28.7 percent in 1996. Industrial growth is targeted at about two percent this year against moderate growth of 0.5 percent in 1996.

However, the Kazakh government, desperate to find cash to meet a mountain of unpaid pensions and wages, wants to increase its budget gap to almost 3.7 percent of gross domestic product from 3.16 percent originally planned.
Pension arrears alone officially total 30 billion tenge ($400 million).
Earlier plans to issue a bond on international markets to find the cash are currently on hold.
